Body:
I am an engineering student and I'm doing a final internship study on IOT (Internet Of Things) using Cassandra as DBMS and a generic server.

I want to know what kind of server used by IOT?

It looks like you are looking for directions more than anything else.

Taking into consideration that IoT is in its infancy, I suggest that you start by looking at some proposed block diagrams for an IoT Solution. Eclipse IoT and ARM mbed provide a nice diagrams laying out typical blocks of an IoT Solution.

For me
column9:
there are three typical types of components in each IoT Solution:

  • The Things that are the leaf of an IoT Solution. A Thing is any object that has a specific purpose contributing to a larger purpose. To accomplish its purpose
column10: it may need to talk to other Things or it may be needed to report its work to other Things or a Server. A Thing could be a very small gadget that senses a physical phenomenon
column11: a consumer machine like a your home fridge or your home TV
column12:
or a full fledged industrial machines.
  • The Servers that are the center. There might be different purposes for this type of component. I can list here at least: administration
column13:
monitoring and Data gathering and analysis.
  • The Gateways that are the intermediate between the Things and the Servers. The purpose of this type of component is to facilitate the connection of the Things to the Servers. By its nature
column14: an IoT Solution will operate in wide area (hence the contribution of Internet). In addition
column15: the Things would have limited communication capabilities. As such
column16:
the Gateway will be here to 'assist' Things while connecting to the Server.

As I said in the beginning
column17: IoT is in its infancy. The above described solution is a Typical Solution as of now
column18: and it is far from being the Solution. However
column19:
I hope it will give you some insight in order to found your direction.

At the end

I see two types of propositions for Open Source IoT Servers:

  • Eclipse IoT
column23:
WSO2 and RedHat offer generic frameworks that would be used to develop specific servers
  • Eclipse SmartHome and Eclipse Scada that offer servers ready for specific need

Body: These are two [packaged solutions](http://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/pre-packaged+software) that are ready-for-use (almost for Eclipse Scada) by end user that targets specific needs. Eclipse SmartHome is tuned to easy implementation of SmartHome solutions: this type of solutions target the automation of daily life in a Home: you can program your mobile to activate AC at your Home when you are 5 min away from your home while coming from Work by car.
what you meant by used to develop specific servers ?

Eclipse IoT, for instance, provides the MQTT broker 'Eclipse Mosquitto', The CoAP server 'Eclipse Californium', and the LWM2M server 'Leshan'. All this systems can be used to develop IoT solutions. They are not packaged solutions that are ready-for-use by end users.	So, for a specific domain (please keep in mind, the IoT covers a huge spectrum of needs), you will come up with a solution developed by you (Business Rules, UI, ...) that takes full advantage of specialized systems (DBMS, MQTT Broker, CoAP Server, LWM2M Server, Big Data Server, ...).
thank you	and for Eclipse SmartHome and Eclipse Scada  provides what?
Here is a nice presentation of an [End-to-end IoT](https://www.parleys.com/talk/543f8e75e4b06e1184ae4115) solution given by the IoT team at Eclipse.

Internet of Things does not need to have a central server. Actually, it will be much better in terms of privacy to have decentralized IoT networks, where user data is stored in their private clouds and federated using open protocols. This is the reasoning behind the PrIoT Manifesto.

I fully support your initiative. It is important that IoT is under the control of people rather than a means to control people. IoT solution should be secure to use and should protect people's privacy.
